title: Le Bernardin-Style Crêpes Suzette
description: This isn't just Crêpes Suzette - it's a masterclass in French dessert technique, inspired by Eric Ripert's Le Bernardin. The secret lies in the perfect crêpe batter consistency, a 24-hour rest period that develops complex flavors, and a carefully calibrated orange-butter sauce that balances sweet, bitter, and acidic notes. The flambé technique isn't just for show - it adds crucial caramelization and reduces the alcohol to its essence.

crêpe batter.name: unsalted butter
crêpe batter.notes: Melted and cooled, plus more for pan

crêpe batter.name: fine sea salt
crêpe batter.notes: Fine sea salt preferred over table salt

orange butter sauce.name: orange zest
orange butter sauce.notes: Remove in wide strips with peeler

instructions.text: PREPARE BATTER (DAY BEFORE): In a blender, combine eggs, egg yolks, milk, cream, melted butter, Grand Marnier, sugar, and salt. Blend for 10 seconds.
ADD FLOUR: With blender running on low speed, gradually add flour. Blend for 30 seconds. Scrape down sides, add orange zest, and blend for another 30 seconds until completely smooth.
REST BATTER: Transfer to a container, cover, and refrigerate for 24 hours. This rest is crucial for tender crêpes.
PREPARE FOR COOKING (NEXT DAY): Remove batter from refrigerator 1 hour before cooking. Whisk gently to recombine. Strain through a fine-mesh sieve if needed.
COOK CRÊPES: Heat an 8-inch crêpe pan or nonstick skillet over medium heat. Brush lightly with melted butter. Pour about 2 tablespoons batter into pan, quickly swirling to coat bottom evenly.

COOK AND FLIP: Cook until edges are lightly golden and top is set, about 1 minute. Flip and cook second side for 30 seconds. Transfer to a plate. Repeat with remaining batter, stacking crêpes between pieces of parchment paper.
PREPARE ORANGE BUTTER SAUCE: In a large skillet over medium heat, combine butter, sugar, and orange zest strips. Cook until butter melts and sugar begins to dissolve.
ADD JUICE: Add orange juice and simmer until sauce thickens slightly and becomes syrupy, about 5 minutes. Remove orange zest strips.
FOLD AND WARM CRÊPES: Working with 2-3 crêpes at a time, fold each into quarters and add to the simmering sauce. Baste with sauce until heated through.
FLAMBÉ: Warm Cognac in a small saucepan. Add to skillet and carefully ignite with a long match. When flames subside, add Grand Marnier and ignite again.
SERVE: Transfer crêpes to warm plates, spooning sauce over top. Serve immediately.

notes: BATTER CONSISTENCY: After resting, the batter should be the consistency of heavy cream. If too thick, thin with a little milk.
TEMPERATURE CONTROL: The pan should be hot enough that the batter sizzles gently when added, but not so hot that the butter browns quickly.
CRÊPE TECHNIQUE: The key to perfectly thin crêpes is quick pan rotation immediately after adding the batter.
SAUCE BALANCE: The sauce should have a perfect balance of sweet, bitter (from caramelization), and acidic notes. Adjust orange juice if needed.
FLAMBÉ SAFETY: Have a lid nearby to smother flames if needed. Never pour alcohol directly from the bottle.
TIMING: Crêpes can be made several hours ahead and reheated in the sauce. The sauce should be made just before serving.
SERVING: At Le Bernardin, these are often served with a small scoop of orange-scented vanilla ice cream.
